t: Job 10
“I*pn loathe my very life; therefore*ld I will give free rein to my complaint and*ld speak out in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ln say to God: Do not declare me guilty, but*ld tell me what charges you have against me.
Does*ln it please you to oppress me, to*ld spurn the work of your hands, while*ld you smile on the plans of the wicked?
Do*ln you have eyes of flesh? Do*ld you see as a mortal sees?
Are*ln your days like those of a mortal or*ld your years like those of a strong man,
that*ln you must search out my faults and*ld probe after my sin—
though*ln you know that I am not guilty and*ld that no one can rescue me from your hand?
“Your*pn hands shaped me and made me. Will*ld you now turn and destroy me?
Remember*ln that you molded me like clay. Will*ld you now turn me to dust again?
Did*ln you not pour me out like milk and*ld curdle me like cheese,
clothe*ln me with skin and flesh and*ld knit me together with bones and sinews?
You*ln gave me life and showed me kindness, and*ld in your providence watched over my spirit.
“But*pn this is what you concealed in your heart, and*ld I know that this was in your mind:
If*ln I sinned, you would be watching me and*ld would not let my offense go unpunished.
If*ln I am guilty—woe to me! Even*ld if I am innocent, I cannot lift my head, for*ln I am full of shame and*ld drowned in my affliction.
If*ln I hold my head high, you stalk me like a lion and*ld again display your awesome power against me.
You*ln bring new witnesses against me and*ld increase your anger toward me; your*ld forces come against me wave upon wave.
“Why*pn then did you bring me out of the womb? I*ld wish I had died before any eye saw me.
If*ln only I had never come into being, or*ld had been carried straight from the womb to the grave!
Are*ln not my few days almost over? Turn*ld away from me so I can have a moment’s joy
before*ln I go to the place of no return, to*ld the land of gloom and utter darkness,
to*ln the land of deepest night, of*ld utter darkness and disorder, where*ld even the light is like darkness.”
